Tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol (THFA) is an important green solvent and a key feedstock for the synthesis of chemicals such as succinic acid, 1,5-pentanediol, tetrahydrofuran, and pyran. In this study, a Ni/CeO₂ catalyst was synthesized via a simple co-precipitation method, which can efficiently catalyze the hydrogenation of biomass-derived furfural to THFA under mild conditions. The catalyst was characterized using XRD, XPS, H₂-TPR, H₂-TPD, and CO₂-TPD. The results indicate that hydrogen molecules adsorb and dissociate into active hydrogen species on the highly dispersed Ni0 active sites, which then rapidly migrate to the catalyst surface to attack adsorbed furfural, generating furfuryl alcohol, which is subsequently hydrogenated to THFA. Additionally, the stability and reusability of the catalyst were thoroughly investigated. The 20Ni/CeO₂ catalyst maintained good catalytic activity after five cycles of reuse. This work demonstrates the potential of non-noble metal Ni-based catalysts for efficient hydrogenation under low-temperature and low-pressure conditions, providing a new approach for the economical and efficient production of THFA. Concurrently, fossil fuels, as the primary energy source, are facing the dilemma of rapid depletion, and their large-scale use has caused severe environmental pollution on Earth [1,2]. Against this backdrop, biomass, as a renewable resource, has garnered significant attention due to its potential to replace fossil fuels for the production of various high-value chemicals [3]. Cellulosic biomass, the largest renewable carbon source, is mainly composed of cellulose, lignin, and hemicellulose, accounting for over 90 % of total plant biomass, and its utilization does not compete with food reserves[4]. Furfural (FA), one of the most valuable chemicals derived from cellulosic biomass [5], has been identified as a key chemical for production in lignocellulosic biorefineries. Currently, about 70 % of the global FA production originates from China, and its industrial production is primarily achieved through the acid-catalyzed conversion of xylan in biomass [6,7]. The selective hydrogenation of FA can generate a variety of high-value chemicals [8], with significant industrial application value. Among these, the complete hydrogenation of FA to tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol (THFA) represents a highly promising route. THFA is an important degradable furan derivative that is widely used as a green solvent in industries such as agriculture and printing. It also serves as a key biomass-derived platform compound for the production of dihydropyran, 1,5-pentanediol(1,5-PeD), industrial resins, and biofuel additives [9]. Currently, the industrial production of THFA involves a two-step process: first, the hydrogenation of FA to furfuryl alcohol (FOL) [10,11], followed by the further hydrogenation of FOL to THFA [12]. However, this multi-step approach suffers from drawbacks such as long production cycles, high costs, and complex procedures. In contrast, a one-pot catalytic conversion of FA directly to THFA can significantly shorten the production cycle, reduce costs, and simplify the process, thus attracting considerable attention. It is worth noting that due to the high energy barrier associated with the hydrogenation of the unsaturated double bond in the furan ring, the hydrogenation of FOL to THFA is the key step in this process, typically requiring higher hydrogen pressure and reaction temperatures [13]. Homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts have both been reported to effectively catalyze the hydrogenation of FA to THFA. However, homogeneous catalysis is plagued by issues such as the difficulty in separating the target product and the tendency of catalysts to deactivate, which has driven the development of heterogeneous catalysts as an inevitable choice for efficient THFA production [14]. Among heterogeneous catalysts, noble-metal catalysts (e.g., Re, Pd, Rh, Pt) have demonstrated superior catalytic activity. For instance, Wei et al. successfully achieved a THFA yield of 97.6 % by ingeniously utilizing the synergistic effect between the abundant Lewis acidity in ReOₓ and nickel nanoparticles and reacting under the conditions of 130 °C and 3 MPa H₂ for 3 h [12]. Yin et al. employed a 3 wt. % Pd@MIL-101(Cr)-NH₂ catalyst to achieve nearly 100 % selectivity in converting FA to THFA at 40 °C and 2 MPa H₂ [15]. Cao et al. utilized an Ru-MoOₓ/CN-10–250A-350H catalyst to obtain a 92 % yield of THFA after 1 h of reaction at 100 °C and 2 MPa H₂ [16]. Additionally, Wu et al. reported a 93 % yield of THFA using a Pt(3)Ni(3)/C catalyst at 35 °C and 2 MPa H₂ over 12 h [17]. These studies highlight the ability of noble-metal catalysts to efficiently catalyze FA hydrogenation to THFA under mild conditions. However, their high cost and scarcity limit large-scale applications. Consequently, non-noble-metal catalysts (e.g., Ni, Cu, Co) have garnered significant attention in recent years. These catalysts have been proven to effectively catalyze the selective hydrogenation of FA to THFA. For example, Zhang et al. successfully prepared the CoNi bimetallic alloy catalyst (xCoyNi/C) by using the one-step pyrolysis of the metal-organic framework (MOF) method [18]. Under the conditions of 110 °C and 2 MPa H2, the yield of THFA exceeded 99 %. Reaction kinetics experiments and theoretical calculations indicate that the key intermediate product for the hydrogenation of FA to THFA is FOL, and reducing the activation energy barrier for the conversion of FOL to THFA is the key to achieving high yields. Zheng et al. developed a nickel-based layered hydroxide (hydrotalcite) -derived catalyst (Ni1Zr1Al2), which was reacted at 140 °C and 2 MPa H2, achieving complete conversion of FA and a selectivity of 94.5 % for THFA [19]. Wang et al. reported a 99.8 % conversion of FA and 99.1 % selectivity to THFA using a NiCo/SiO₂-MOF catalyst at 80 °C and 3 MPa H₂ over 8 h [20]. Su et al. achieved a near 100 % yield of THFA using a Ni/C-500 catalyst at 120 °C and 1 MPa H₂ over 2 h [21]. Although non-noble metal catalysts have made significant progress in the hydrogenation of FA to produce THFA, compared with noble metal catalysts, they usually require higher reaction temperatures and pressures (>2 MPa) to achieve efficient conversion. Furthermore, research on non-precious metal catalysts in the hydrogenation of furan rings and the hydrogenation of FA to THFA is still relatively limited. Therefore, the development of non-noble-metal catalysts capable of efficiently catalyzing the selective hydrogenation of FA to THFA under low-temperature and low-pressure conditions remains of significant research and practical value. Traditional oxides (such as SiO₂, TiO₂, MgO, and Al₂O₃) have been widely employed as supports to anchor active centers for the hydrogenation of FA [22,23]. In recent years, the development of rare-earth oxides as supports has garnered increasing attention, with CeO₂ emerging as a standout candidate due to its unique multivalence. The reversible conversion between Ce³⁺ and Ce⁴⁺ facilitates the formation and elimination of oxygen vacancies, creating defect structures that can further enhance the catalytic performance of CeO₂ through doping or loading with other transition metals. In the hydrogenation of FA to THFA, metals from Group VIII (such as Ni, Ru, Rh, Pd, and Pt) have demonstrated favorable catalytic activities [20]. Among them, Ni, as a non-noble metal, has been extensively utilized in various hydrogenation reactions due to its remarkable hydrogenation capability [24]. Building on this research background, the present study developed a nickel-based non-noble metal catalyst supported on CeO₂ and systematically investigated its catalytic performance in the conversion of FA to THFA. The physicochemical properties of the catalyst were characterized using XRD, XPS, H₂-TPR, H₂-TPD, CO₂-TPD and TEM, and the effects of nickel loading, reaction temperature, time, and pressure on the reaction were explored. Additionally, this study elucidated the reaction pathway and mechanism of Ni/CeO2 in the selective hydrogenation of FA to THFA, providing a theoretical basis for the development of efficient non-noble metal catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation In this study, a series of Ni/CeO2 catalysts with varying Ni loading ratios were prepared by the co-precipitation method. First, according to the predetermined molar ratio, the volumes of salt solutions of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O and Ce(NO3)3·6H2O were measured in a beaker and mixed well under stirring conditions, respectively. Subsequently, a 0.5 M NaOH solution was added drop by drop to the above mixed solution under high-speed stirring conditions until a precipitate was formed. The resulting precipitated system was subjected to a 24 h aging period at room temperature, followed by filtration. The precipitate was then washed multiple times with deionized water. Subsequently, the washed precipitate was dried at 393 K for a duration of 24 h. The dried solid was ground into powder and calcined in a hydrogen atmosphere at 723 K for a duration of 3 h. The resultant catalyst, designated as xNi/CeO₂, was obtained, where x denotes the mass fraction (in percentage) of Ni in the catalyst. Moreover, Ni/Al2O3, Ni/ZnO, Ni/Y2O3, and Ni/SiO2 catalysts were prepared by analogous methods for the purpose of comparative studies. 2.2 Catalytic testing conditions The catalytic conversion reaction of FA was carried out in a 50 mL stainless steel autoclave. First, 1 mmol of FA was dissolved in 10 mL of isopropanol (IPA) to prepare the reaction substrate solution. Subsequently, 100 mg of catalyst was added to the solution, and the mixture was thoroughly mixed before being placed in the sealed high-pressure reactor. Nitrogen gas was introduced to replace the air 4–5 times, followed by 4–5 cycles of hydrogen gas substitution. Afterward, hydrogen gas was introduced into the reactor to the target pressure. The reactor was then heated to the target temperature under stirring at 500 rpm and maintained at that temperature for a specified duration to allow the reaction to proceed. Upon completion of the reaction, the liquid product sample was collected from the reactor and analyzed using gas chromatography. After the reaction, the catalyst was washed several times with ethanol, followed by centrifugation, and then placed in a vacuum drying oven at 323 K overnight to recover the catalyst for subsequent use. The conversion of FA, product selectivity, and yield were calculated with the relevant calculation formulas provided below: Conversion = Moles of reacted FA Moles of initial FA × 100 % Selectivity ( % ) = Moles of specific product Moles of reacted FA × 100 % Yield = [ Conversion ( % ) × Selectivity ( % ) ] × 100 % 2.3 Characterization techniques X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis of the samples was conducted on a Rigaku Smart Lab SE high-power powder diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54 Å) at 40 kV and 50 mA. Data were collected in the 2θ range of 5°–90° at a scan rate of 10 °/min. The nitrogen adsorption and desorption isotherms of the samples were measured at 77 K using an ASAP-2460 high-performance static surface area analyzer. The surface area was calculated using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) equation from the desorption isotherm. All samples were degassed at 473 K under vacuum for 10 h before measurement. The internal microstructural morphology of the samples was observed using a FEI Tecnai G2 F20 transmission electron microscope (TEM). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis of the prepared catalysts was performed using Al Kα radiation (hv = 1486.6 eV) on a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha spectrometer with a spot size of 400 μm, operating at 12 kV and 6 mA. The non-fixed carbon charging effect was corrected using the C1s peak at 284.8 eV, and binding energies were calibrated accordingly. The mass change of the samples with temperature was measured using a Netzsch STA 409 PC differential thermal-thermogravimetric analyzer. The gas flow was set to 40 mL/min, with a heating range from 35 °C to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min. Temperature-programmed reduction (H₂-TPR) analysis of the catalyst was performed using a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 instrument. For the experiment, 50–80 mg of sample was placed in a U-shaped quartz tube and dried by heating from room temperature to 400 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min. Afterward, the sample was flushed with 50 mL/min helium for 1 h, then cooled to 50 °C, and a 10 % H₂/Ar mixture (50 mL/min) was introduced to stabilize the baseline for 0.5 h. The sample was then heated to 600 °C at 10 °C/min under a 10 % H₂/Ar flow for reduction, and the gases during reduction were monitored by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Hydrogen temperature-programmed desorption (H₂-TPD) analysis was performed using the Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 instrument. In the experiment, 100 mg of sample was placed in a reaction tube, dried by heating from room temperature to 150 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min, and then purged with 30–50 mL/min helium for 1 h. After cooling to 50 °C, a 10 % H₂/Ar mixture (30–50 mL/min) was introduced for 1 h to saturate the sample surface, followed by switching to the same flow rate of Ar for 1 h to remove weakly adsorbed hydrogen. Finally, under an Ar atmosphere, the temperature was ramped to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min for desorption analysis, with the desorbed gases monitored by a TCD. After cooling to 50 °C, a 10 % CO₂/He mixture (30–50 mL/min) was introduced for 1 h to saturate the sample surface, followed by switching to the same flow rate of helium for 1 h to remove weakly adsorbed CO₂. The temperature rises from 35 °C to 800 °C, and the heating rate is 10 °C/min. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization To investigate the crystallographic phase composition of the catalyst and determine the relative content of each phase, X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was systematically performed, with the results shown in Fig. 1 a. In the XRD patterns of the 15Ni/CeO₂ and 20Ni/CeO₂ catalysts, no distinct diffraction peaks corresponding to NiO or Ni0 were observed, indicating that the nickel species are highly dispersed on the CeO₂ support in these catalysts[25]. This highly dispersed nature prevents the formation of sufficiently large crystals of nickel species to generate detectable diffraction signals. However, in the XRD pattern of the 25Ni/CeO₂ catalyst, weak diffraction peaks corresponding to Ni0 can be observed, suggesting that as the nickel loading increases, the initially highly dispersed Ni nanoparticles gradually aggregate. This phenomenon indicates that moderate nickel loading helps maintain the high dispersion of nickel species, while excessively high loading may lead to the aggregation of Ni nanoparticles. Additionally, XRD analysis revealed only Ni0 diffraction peaks in all catalysts, with no NiO diffraction peaks detected, which clearly indicates that the nickel species in the prepared catalysts primarily exist in the metallic Ni⁰ form. Meanwhile, the cerium species showed diffraction peaks at 2θ of 28.54°, 33.07°, 47.46°, and 56.32°, corresponding to the (111), (200), (220), and (311) crystal planes of CeO2 (PDF#34–0394), and all of them existed in the form of CeO₂ in catalysts. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) were employed to analyze the morphology, average particle size, and surface lattice structure of the catalyst. As shown in Fig. 2 a-b, the 20Ni/CeO₂ catalyst exhibits an irregular nanosheet-like particle structure. Through TEM particle size distribution analysis, the average particle size of the sample was determined to be 5.14 nm. In the HRTEM analysis, lattice fringes with interplanar spacings of 0.32 nm (d1), 0.27 nm (d2), 0.20 nm (d3), and 0.17 nm (d4) were observed, which correspond to the CeO₂ (111), CeO₂ (200), Ni⁰ (111), and Ni⁰ (200) crystal planes, respectively. Notably, no lattice fringes corresponding to NiO or Ce₂O₃ species were observed in the HRTEM images, indicating that the Ni and Ce species in the catalyst primarily exist in the metallic Ni⁰ and CeO₂ forms (This is consistent with the XRD results). The TEM results confirm the high dispersion and good reducibility of Ni species in the catalyst, as well as the stable structure of the CeO₂ support. Furthermore, N₂ adsorption-desorption isotherm analysis was employed to investigate the pore structure and specific surface area characteristics of the catalysts. As shown in Fig. 1b, according to the IUPAC classification, the 15Ni/CeO₂, 20Ni/CeO₂, and 25Ni/CeO₂ catalysts all exhibit typical type IV isotherms, indicating that they are mesoporous materials. Notably, the adsorption-desorption isotherm of the 20Ni/CeO₂ catalyst shows a typical H₃ hysteresis loop, which is typically associated with sheet-like particle materials, consistent with the results obtained earlier through TEM analysis. Based on the low-temperature N₂ adsorption-desorption experimental data, the physical properties of the samples, including specific surface area, pore volume, and average pore diameter, were calculated using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) and Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) methods, as shown in Table 1 . The 25Ni/CeO₂ catalyst exhibits the smallest specific surface area (56.2 m²/g), a pore volume of 0.10 cm³/g, and an average pore diameter of 7.09 nm. As the nickel loading decreases, the 20Ni/CeO₂ catalyst shows the largest specific surface area (70.9 m²/g), pore volume (0.14 cm³/g), and average pore diameter (7.56 nm). Further reducing the nickel loading to 15 % results in a decrease in specific surface area to 61.5 m²/g, pore volume to 0.06 cm³/g, and average pore diameter to 5.12 nm. The average pore diameters of all catalysts fall within the mesoporous range (2 –50 nm). The 20Ni/CeO₂ catalyst, with its larger specific surface area, pore volume, and average pore diameter, facilitates the high dispersion of Ni species and the mass transfer process during the FA hydrogenation reaction, thereby exhibiting the best catalytic activity, which is consistent with the experimental results. Given the observed decline in THFA yield after multiple cycles of catalyst use, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was performed on both the fresh catalyst and the catalyst after five cycles of use to identify the potential causes of this reduction in yield. The results (shown in Fig. 3 a-b) indicate that, compared to the fresh catalyst, the valence state of Ce species in the used catalyst did not undergo significant changes. However, a notable shift in the valence state distribution of Ni species was observed: the proportion of Ni⁰ decreased, while the proportion of Ni²⁺ increased. This suggests that during the catalytic cycling process, part of the Ni⁰ species was oxidized to Ni²⁺. Therefore, the decline in catalytic activity of the 20Ni/CeO₂ catalyst during recycling may be attributed to the partial oxidation of nickel species during the recovery and reuse process. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was conducted on the 20Ni/CeO₂ catalyst and its precursor to assess the catalyst's thermal stability and structural changes under high-temperature conditions. The TG curves are shown in Fig. 4 a. During the heating process from room temperature to 150 °C, the mass loss of both the 20Ni/CeO₂ catalyst and its precursor is primarily attributed to the removal of a small amount of crystallized water in the catalyst. At approximately 300 °C, the mass loss of the 20Ni/CeO2 catalyst precursor can be attributed to the decomposition of the hydroxide precipitate formed during the co-precipitation process [26]. Overall, the thermogravimetric curve shows that, after calcination at 750 °C, the 20Ni/CeO₂ catalyst precursor lost some mass due to the decomposition of hydroxides; however, it still retained >80 % of its original mass. In contrast, the reduced 20Ni/CeO₂ catalyst exhibited a mass retention of over 95 % after calcination at 750 °C, demonstrating excellent thermal stability. To investigate the reduction behavior of Ni/CeO₂, H₂-TPR characterization was performed. In the H₂-TPR spectrum (Fig. 4b), three prominent hydrogen consumption peaks, labeled as α, β, and θ, can be observed. According to studies in the literature [27–29], the α peak primarily arises from the reduction of NiO species that are highly dispersed on the CeO₂ support; the β peak is attributed to the reduction of NiO species interacting with Ni nanoparticles; and the θ peak corresponds to the reduction of surface CeO₂. Furthermore, with the increase in Ni loading, the hydrogen consumption gradually increases, and all the reduction peaks of Ni-Ce shift towards lower temperatures. With the increase of Ni loading, Ni species gradually aggregate on the CeO₂ surface, forming larger Ni particles (confirmed by XRD results). This aggregation leads to a weakened interaction between Ni and CeO₂, thereby reducing the overall reduction temperature of the catalyst [30,31]. To investigate the hydrogen adsorption and desorption characteristics on the catalyst surface, hydrogen temperature-programmed desorption (H₂-TPD) was employed for characterization. As shown in Fig. 4c, the 15Ni/CeO₂ sample exhibits a sharp hydrogen desorption peak at 272 °C, which is attributed to the strong adsorption and activation ability of hydrogen on the Ni particles. This indicates that Ni is highly dispersed in this sample [32]. Further studies reveal that when the Ni loading reaches 20 %, the hydrogen desorption temperature reaches its minimum, indicating that the 20Ni/CeO₂ catalyst demonstrates the most excellent hydrogen activation and desorption ability at this loading (consistent with our experimental results) [33]. However, with a further increase in Ni loading, the hydrogen desorption temperature increases. This trend can be attributed to the gradual aggregation of Ni nanoparticles on the catalyst surface, leading to the formation of larger particles, which in turn increases the energy required for hydrogen desorption, consistent with the XRD results. In addition, the concentration and distribution of basic sites on the catalyst surface were characterized using carbon dioxide temperature-programmed desorption (CO₂-TPD). According to the literature [34,35], the CO₂-TPD curve can be divided into three regions: weak basic sites (100–230 °C), moderately strong basic sites (230–500 °C), and strong basic sites (>500 °C). The analysis results show that pure CeO₂ exhibits a certain amount of weakly basic and moderately strongly basic sites. After the introduction of Ni, the number of weakly basic sites decreased, while the number of moderately and strongly basic sites increased. It can be seen that the introduction of Ni optimizes the distribution of basic sites. These moderately strong basic sites are conducive to the adsorption of substrates, thereby promoting the hydrogenation reaction of FA [36,37]. 3.2 Catalysts testing In the hydrogenation of FA to THFA, the saturation of the C = C bond on the furan ring is the key step, with a higher reaction barrier than the hydrogenation of the aldehyde group. Therefore, an ideal catalyst should possess high hydrogenation activity while suppressing the hydrogenolysis of FA to reduce the formation of by-products such as 2-methylfuran (2-MF) and 1,5-PeD. In this study, a series of supported nickel-based catalysts were prepared via co-precipitation and tested for catalytic performance in a reaction conducted at 150 °C and 2 MPa H₂ pressure for 12 h (Table 2 ). The results indicate that catalysts supported on SiO₂ and ZnO (Ni/SiO₂, Ni/ZnO) primarily convert FA to FOL, with low yields of THFA. In contrast, catalysts supported on CeO₂, Al₂O₃, and Y₂O₃ (Ni/CeO₂, Ni/Al₂O₃, Ni/Y₂O₃) exhibit higher selectivity for THFA. The Ni/CeO₂ catalyst demonstrated the highest yield of THFA and the least by-product generation in the reaction, while also having the highest TOF value. This indicates that on the CeO2 carrier, the Ni active sites were the most active and the catalytic performance was the best. A series of Ni/CeO₂ catalysts with different nickel loadings were prepared using the same method, and their catalytic performance for the hydrogenation of FA to THFA was evaluated under conditions of 120 °C and 2.0 MPa H₂ (Fig. 5 a). The results show that the 5 % Ni/CeO₂ catalyst achieved a FA conversion of 35.3 % after 6 h, with selectivity for FOL and THFA of 8.0 % and 78.0 %, respectively. When the nickel loading increased from 5 % to 10 %, the FA conversion significantly improved to 98.0 %, with selectivity for FOL and THFA of 41.7 % and 45.2 %, respectively. Further increasing the nickel loading to 20 % resulted in complete conversion of FA within 6 h, with no FOL formed, and the selectivity for THFA reached 90.4 %. However, when the nickel loading was increased to 25 %, the selectivity for THFA slightly decreased, likely due to the increased Ni²⁺ content, which promoted the formation of by-products [38,39]. The effect of the catalyst loading of 20Ni/CeO₂ on the hydrogenation of FA to THFA was investigated under reaction conditions of 120 °C and 2.0 MPa H₂ (Fig. 5b). The results show that as the catalyst loading increased from 25 mg to 100 mg, the yield of THFA continuously increased. However, when the catalyst loading was further increased to 125 mg, the yield of THFA decreased. This decline may be attributed to the increase in Ni²⁺ content in the system as the catalyst loading increased, which in turn promoted the formation of by-products. Subsequently, the effect of reaction temperature on the hydrogenation of FA to THFA was investigated under a hydrogen pressure of 2.0 MPa, as shown in Fig. 5c. As the reaction temperature increased from 80 °C to 90 °C, the FA conversion increased from 66.4 % to 100 %, while the selectivity for THFA and FOL both significantly improved. When the temperature was further increased to 100 °C, the selectivity for FOL sharply decreased, while the selectivity for THFA significantly increased. Upon further heating to 110 °C, the selectivity for THFA slightly increased. However, when the temperature was raised to 120 °C, the selectivity for THFA noticeably decreased, while the selectivity for n-butanol (1-BuOH) and tetrahydrofuran (THF) increased. This indicates that at higher temperatures, both the hydrogenation and hydrogenolysis activities of the catalyst are enhanced, leading to changes in the product distribution [40]. The effect of reaction time on the product distribution was studied under conditions of 100 °C and 1.0 MPa H₂ (Fig. 5d). As the reaction time was extended from 0.5 h to 3 h, FA was gradually and completely transformed. The selectivity of FOL first increased and then decreased, while the selectivity of THFA continued to rise and finally reached 96.8 %. However, after further prolongating the reaction time, THFA continued to transform, and by-products such as 1-BuOH and THF increased, resulting in a decrease in the yield of THFA. Finally, the effect of reaction pressure on the product distribution of catalytic hydrogenation was investigated, as shown in Fig. 6 . At a hydrogen pressure of 0.1 MPa, the conversion of FA after 3 h was 76.8 %, with selectivity for FOL and THFA of 64.7 % and 22.0 %, respectively. As the hydrogen pressure increased to 0.5 MPa, FA was almost completely converted within 3 h, with a decrease in the selectivity for FOL and an increase in the selectivity for THFA. When the hydrogen pressure was further increased to 1.0 MPa, FOL was completely converted to THFA, and the selectivity for THFA reached 96.8 %. Continuing to raise the hydrogen pressure to 2.0 MPa, the selectivity for THFA remained stable with little change. 3.3 Reaction pathway and mechanism Based on the experimental data obtained and relevant studies reported in the literature, a possible reaction pathway for the conversion of FA to THFA and other products over the 20Ni/CeO₂ catalyst is proposed, as shown in Fig. 7 . The aldehyde group in the FA molecule undergoes hydrogenation to form FOL. Further hydrogenation of the furan ring in FOL leads to the formation of THFA. The CO bond near the hydroxymethyl group in the THFA molecule can undergo hydrogenolysis, resulting in the formation of 1,5-PeD. Under specific conditions, the hydroxymethyl group on the furan ring of FOL can undergo hydrogenolysis, converting it to 2-MF. FA can also undergo hydrogenolysis to eliminate the aldehyde group, leading to decarbonylation followed by hydrogenation to form THF. Subsequently, THF can undergo hydrogenolysis to open the ring, resulting in the formation of 1-BuOH. Based on the experimental data, characterization results, and previously reported studies, a reaction mechanism for the conversion of FA to THFA over the 20Ni/CeO₂ catalyst is proposed (Fig. 8 ). At an appropriate reaction temperature, the aldehyde oxygen and furan ring in the FA molecule are adsorbed by the abundant basic sites on the surface of the catalyst. Subsequently, the Ni⁰ surface efficiently activates the hydrogen molecules, and the generated active hydrogen species attack the aldehyde groups adsorbed on the surface of the catalyst, hydrogenating and reducing them to hydroxymethyl groups. Thus, FA is converted to FOL and further hydrogenated to THFA. 3.4 Stability tests of 20Ni/CeO2 The cyclic stability of the 20Ni/CeO₂ catalyst in the hydrogenation of FA was investigated under conditions of 100 °C and 1.0 MPa (Fig. 9 ). When fresh catalyst was used, FA was completely converted within 4 h, with a selectivity of 95.3 % towards THFA. After three cycles, the catalyst performance remained stable, with a selectivity of 91.8 % for THFA. After five cycles, although the selectivity for THFA decreased, it remained above 80 %. The catalyst that had been recycled for 5 times was subjected to H₂ re-reduction treatment (Run 6) and reintroduced into the reaction. The results showed that the activity of the catalyst was restored, proving that the slight deactivation of the catalyst was caused by the oxidation of part of the Ni0. Compared to recently reported nickel-based catalysts (Table 3 ), the 20Ni/CeO₂ catalyst synthesized in this study demonstrates significant advantages in the hydrogenation of FA to THFA. Under extremely mild reaction conditions (100 °C, 1.0 MPa), the 20Ni/CeO₂ catalyst achieves catalytic activity comparable to that of similar nickel-based catalysts, but with a lower reaction pressure. Coupled with its simple preparation method, lower preparation cost, and good cyclic stability, the 20Ni/CeO₂ catalyst shows considerable competitiveness for practical applications and holds great potential to advance the industrialization of FA hydrogenation to THFA. 4 Conclusion In this study, a series of nickel-based ceria catalysts were synthesized, among which the 20Ni/CeO₂ catalyst exhibited outstanding performance in the hydrogenation of FA. Under reaction conditions of 100 °C, 1 MPa H₂ pressure, and isopropanol solvent for 3 h, the 20Ni/CeO₂ catalyst efficiently catalyzed the conversion of FA to THFA, achieving a yield of up to 96.8 %. Characterization and experimental results revealed that basic sites on the catalyst surface adsorb FA, while highly dispersed Ni⁰ sites are crucial for efficient hydrogenation. H₂ dissociates on Ni⁰ sites into active hydrogen species, which are then transferred to the adsorbed FA surface, enabling its complete hydrogenation. Ni/CeO₂ achieves efficient hydrogenation of FA under mild conditions and exhibits good thermal stability, providing an important reference for the industrialization of non-precious metal Ni-based catalysts and their application in hydrogenation processes. coredata.dc:description: Tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol (THFA) is an important green solvent and a key feedstock for the synthesis of chemicals such as succinic acid, 1,5-pentanediol, tetrahydrofuran, and pyran. In this study, a Ni/CeO₂ catalyst was synthesized via a simple co-precipitation method, which can efficiently catalyze the hydrogenation of biomass-derived furfural to THFA under mild conditions. The catalyst was characterized using XRD, XPS, H₂-TPR, H₂-TPD, and CO₂-TPD. The results indicate that hydrogen molecules adsorb and dissociate into active hydrogen species on the highly dispersed Ni0 active sites, which then rapidly migrate to the catalyst surface to attack adsorbed furfural, generating furfuryl alcohol, which is subsequently hydrogenated to THFA. Additionally, the stability and reusability of the catalyst were thoroughly investigated. The 20Ni/CeO₂ catalyst maintained good catalytic activity after five cycles of reuse. This work demonstrates the potential of non-noble metal Ni-based catalysts for efficient hydrogenation under low-temperature and low-pressure conditions, providing a new approach for the economical and efficient production of THFA.
